question.title: Why must my method take an ActionEvent when using this::methodName with addActionListener?
question.body:
I’m working on a simple Swing GUI in Java and have a method addListeners() where I attach an ActionListener to a button like this:

increase.addActionListener(this::increasePoints);

However, this line is marked red in my IDE and won’t compile unless I change the method increasePoints to accept an ActionEvent as a parameter:

    points++;
    textField.setText(Integer.toString(points));
}

Originally, I had:

private void increasePoints() {
    points++;
    textField.setText(Integer.toString(points));
}

My question is: Does it have to be written like this? Is there no cleaner or better way? Why exactly do I have to add an ActionEvent parameter, even if I do not use it?

Any clarification would be greatly appreciated! I’m trying to understand not just how to fix it, but why this is necessary.

Here is the full relevant code:

private void addListeners() {
    increase.addActionListener(this::increasePoints);

    // This version works too:
    // increase.addActionListener(new ActionListener() {
    //     @Override
    //     public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
    //         increasePoints();
    //     }
    // });

    decrease.addActionListener(new ActionListener() {
        @Override
        public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
            decreasePoints();
        }
    });
}

private void increasePoints() {
    points++;
    textField.setText(Integer.toString(points));
}
